DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: CARRERA JNIOR, J. M.;CARRERA, J. M. Jr.;CARRERA, J. M.;CARRERA, Jose Marcos;CARRERA, JOS MARCOS;Carrera, Jos Marcos;Carrera, Jose Marcos;Carrera, J.M.;CARRERA, J.M.;Carrera, J. M.

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Forte experincia em Finanas Corporativas, M&A, Valuation e Controladoria adquirida durante a vida acadmica e profissional em consultorias, boutique de investimento e em grandes multinacionais, tendo participado de diversas transaes nacionais e internacionais. Atualmente Assessor Financeiro e Professor de Finanas Corporativas. Doutor pela Fundao Getulio Vargas (EAESP-FGV), com estgio doutoral na Universidade de Columbia em Nova York com publicao nos melhores peridicos cientficos internacionais; Mestre em Administrao de Empresas pela Fundao Getulio Vargas (EAESP-FGV), e Mestre em Finanas pela Universidade de So Paulo (FEA-USP); formado em Administrao de Empresas pela Universidade de So Paulo (FEA-USP). Professor de Mtodos Quantitativos Aplicados ao Mercado Financeiro na UNIFESP - Universidade Federal de So Paulo, FIA, FECAP, FGV In Company, Ibmec In Company e Saint Paul Escola de Negcios, e Financial Advisor na Plata Capital Partners e na Pezco Economics & Business Intelligence. Scio fundador do Finanas 101, canal no YouTube com vdeos e aulas de finanas e economia.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Strong experience and financial expertise in Corporate Finance, M&A, Valuation, FP&A and Controllership acquired during the academic and professional career in consulting, advisory and in large multinationals, having participated in several national and international transactions. Financial Advisor and Professor of Corporate Finance. Ph.D. from Fundao Getulio Vargas (EAESP-FGV), Visiting Scholar at Columbia University in the city of New York with publication in the best international scientific journals; Master in Business Administration from Fundao Getulio Vargas (EAESP-FGV), and Master in Finance from Universidade de So Paulo (FEA-USP). Bachelor of Business Administration from the University of So Paulo (FEA-USP). Professor of Quantitative Methods Applied to the Financial Markets at UNIFESP - Federal University of So Paulo, and Professor of Finance at FIA, FECAP, FGV In Company, Ibmec In Company and Saint Paul Business School. Financial Advisor at Plata Capital Partners and at Pezco Economics & Business Intelligence. Founding partner of Finance 101, YouTube channel with lectures on finance and economics.

- 2006-2007 ? Melhor Trabalho Administrativo Voluntrio: PESC ? Programa de Extenso de Servios Comunidade da FEA-USP: Consultoria para o CEAF (Centro de Estudos e Assistncia Famlia) ? ?Imagem e Captao de Recursos?

- 2004-2010 ? Trabalho Voluntrio: Participao na fundao e nas atividades da Associao Atltica Dois Crregos (AADC) ? ONG que visa desenvolver o esporte entre os jovens

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Openness, international champions, and the internationalization of Multilatinas
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Openness, international champions, and the internationalization of Multilatinas

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In the 1990s Latin American countries abandoned their policies of import-substituting industrialization carried out through fully-owned state enterprises (SOEs). They opened their economies to international competition and privatized their SOEs. We argue that this pragmatic adaptation did not necessarily constitute a fundamental change in policies, long followed by some Latin American countries, of state intervention in the pursuit of nationalistic objectives, but is instead a continuation of these policies by other means. Specifically, to safeguard their autonomy, some Latin American states have selected and nurtured domestic firms to become multinational enterprises (MNEs). They have kept ? and obtained ? equity stakes in these national MNEs to influence them and to keep them out of the hands of foreigners. These policies explain the timing of the rise of Multilatinas and their, usually partial, state ownership.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Emerging Market Global Players: The Case of Brazil, China and South Africa

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TEXTO.TITULO-DO-TEXTO: Anos de Instabilidade: crise poltica e econmica e fim do ciclo das commodities so obstculos ao crescimento das multinacionais brasileiras

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRA-PRODUCAO.TITULO: 2016 ? Leading Brazilian Multinational Enterprises: Trends in an Era of Significant Uncertainties and Challenges

DETALHAMENTO-DE-OUTRA-PRODUCAO.EDITORA: The Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment - CCSI

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The Center of International Financial Management Studies (IFM) of the So Paulo School of Business Administration (EAESP) of Fundao Getulio Vargas (FGV), Brazil, and the Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment (CCSI), a joint center of Columbia Law School and The Earth Institute at Columbia University in New York, are releasing the results of the annual survey of Brazilian multinational enterprises (MNEs). The survey is part of the Emerging Market Global Players (EMGP) Project, a long-term study of the rapid global expansion of multinational enterprises (MNEs) from emerging markets. The survey, conducted in 2015, covers the period of 2014.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: The Impact of Ownership Structure on the Internationalization of Brazilian Companies
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: The Impact of Ownership Structure on the Internationalization of Brazilian Companies

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: AIB-2014 - Academy of International Business Meeting 2014

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: An agency problem between shareholders and managers may arise in internationalization decisions, in which the bargaining power of the parties is a function of the ownership concentration. The type of ownership of the firm can also affect the degree of internationalization. Therefore this article examines the influence that ownership structure has on the degree of internationalization of Brazilian companies. By analyzing 184 Brazilian public firms from 2002 to 2011, we rejected the hypothesis of the existence of the mentioned agency problem between shareholders and managers. Further, we show that family businesses and firms with strong government involvement by means of pension funds had, on average, a higher degree of internationalization, which suggests the important role of the government with respect to stimulating the internationalization of private groups.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: An agency problem between shareholders and managers may arise in internationalization decisions, in which the bargaining power of the parties is a function of the ownership concentration. The type of ownership of the firm can also affect the degree of internationalization. Therefore this article examines the influence that ownership structure has on the degree of internationalization of Brazilian companies. By analyzing 184 Brazilian public firms from 2002 to 2011, we rejected the hypothesis of the existence of the mentioned agency problem between shareholders and managers. Further, we show that family businesses and firms with strong government involvement by means of pension funds had, on average, a higher degree of internationalization, which suggests the important role of the government with respect to stimulating the internationalization of private groups.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: Openness, International Champions, and the Internationalization of Multilatinas

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.LOCAL-DA-APRESENTACAO: SIPA - School of International and Public Affairs - Universidade de Columbia

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In the 1990s Latin American countries abandoned their policies of import-substituting industrialization carried out through fully-owned state enterprises (SOEs). They opened their economies to international competition and privatized their SOEs. We argue that this pragmatic adaptation did not necessarily constitute a fundamental change in policies, long followed by some Latin American countries, of state intervention in the pursuit of nationalistic objectives, but is instead a continuation of these policies by other means. Specifically, to safeguard their autonomy, some Latin American states have selected and nurtured domestic firms to become multinational enterprises (MNEs). They have kept ? and obtained ? equity stakes in these national MNEs to influence them and to keep them out of the hands of foreigners. These policies explain the timing of the rise of Multilatinas and their, usually partial, state ownership.
